insights.summary: The NeuroReach VR system aims to improve stroke rehabilitation by focusing on specific motor skills with multi-sensory feedback and adaptive challenges.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system is designed to aid stroke survivors in regaining reach and grasp movements through gamified mixed-reality exercises, specifically a pouring task aligned with ARAT standards and an MX Ink tracing task (c0001). This rehabilitation approach incorporates visual cues like halos and virtual particles, auditory signals, and haptic feedback to guide and reinforce selective muscle activation (c0001, c0004). An adaptive controller dynamically adjusts task difficulty and feedback levels based on real-time performance metrics, transitioning from performance feedback to results feedback to enhance user engagement and learning (c0002). However, the specific stroke rehabilitation goals and target patient population are not detailed (c0001).

1
NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

provenance.chunk_text:
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty
and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.
REFERENCES
[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

insights.summary: Technical hurdles in maintaining system stability and providing consistent feedback are being addressed through proposed solutions and adaptive control mechanisms.
insights.text: The development of the NeuroReach VR system faces significant technical challenges, including anchor drift, inaccurate tilt estimation, and unreliable haptic feedback (c0003). To combat anchor drift, the system will be re-localized at the start of each session, and sensor data like tilt estimation will be filtered and debounced to improve accuracy (c0003). The adaptive controller, while intended to personalize the rehabilitation experience, must overcome issues like overshooting difficulty adjustments and metric drift, which are being managed through moving averages and buffered data writes (c0003). Despite claims of real-time feedback, the evidence points to challenges in achieving stable and consistent feedback mechanisms (c0002).

insights.summary: The system's motivational aspects and performance tracking are intended to enhance user engagement, though some details remain unconfirmed.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system aims to increase user motivation through gamified elements and a projected dashboard displaying key performance metrics (c0002). While the claim suggests gamification for motivation, the evidence does not explicitly confirm its integration (c0001). The projected dashboard is intended to show metrics such as on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC, updated per trial (c0002). However, the evidence only partially lists these metrics and their implementation status, indicating an incomplete picture of the performance tracking capabilities (c0002).

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty
and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.
REFERENCES
[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

actions.title: Clarify Target Patient Population and Specific Stroke Rehabilitation Goals
actions.detail: The current claims describe the NeuroReach VR system's capabilities for reach and grasp training but lack specificity regarding the exact stroke rehabilitation goals (e.g., specific functional deficits addressed) and the target patient population (e.g., stroke phase, severity of impairment). Clarifying these aspects will allow for a more precise understanding of the system's intended impact and clinical utility.

actions.title: Hypothesize the Impact of Gamification on Long-Term Adherence
actions.detail: While the system is designed with gamified elements to increase motivation (c0001, c0002), the long-term effectiveness of these elements in promoting sustained user adherence to the rehabilitation program is not yet established. A hypothesis to explore is whether the gamified elements will translate into better long-term functional outcomes and patient engagement compared to non-gamified approaches.

actions.title: Investigate the Clinical Efficacy of ARAT-Aligned Tasks
actions.detail: The pouring task is designed to be ARAT-aligned (c0004), which is a recognized assessment tool. However, the evidence does not yet demonstrate the clinical efficacy of these specific ARAT-aligned tasks within the NeuroReach VR system in improving actual ARAT scores or other functional measures in stroke survivors. A next step would be to plan for clinical trials to validate this.

actions.title: Clarify the Status and Implementation of All Projected Dashboard Metrics
actions.detail: The projected dashboard is mentioned to display performance metrics (c0002), but only a partial list is provided, and the implementation status of each metric is not fully detailed. Clarification is needed on which metrics are fully implemented, which are in development, and how they will be used to inform the adaptive controller and patient progress tracking.

actions.title: Hypothesize the Correlation Between Sensor Feedback Consistency and Rehabilitation Outcomes
actions.detail: The system aims to provide multi-sensory feedback (c0001), but technical challenges with consistent haptic support and tilt estimation exist (c0003). A hypothesis to investigate is whether the consistency and reliability of this feedback directly correlate with the effectiveness of the rehabilitation, particularly in improving selective muscle activation and overall motor control.

challenges.claim_text: The project's primary goal is to develop a mixed-reality system called NeuroReach VR for stroke rehabilitation. This system will focus on training reach and grasp movements using an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task. The training will incorporate visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to enhance selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors. The system is designed to be intuitive and motivational through gamified elements, suggesting potential for clinical application.
challenges.summary: The evidence does not detail the specific stroke rehabilitation goals or the target patient population for the NeuroReach VR system.
challenges.detail: The claim states that the NeuroReach VR system is for stroke rehabilitation and focuses on training reach and grasp movements. However, the provided evidence snippets (E1 and E2) describe the technical development of the system, including adaptive controllers, logging, VR tasks, and multimodal feedback. They do not specify which types of stroke or what stage of recovery the system is intended for, nor do they mention the specific rehabilitation goals beyond the general training of movements. This leaves unanswered questions about the system's clinical applicability and target user group within the broader context of stroke rehabilitation.

challenges.claim_text: The system will provide real-time feedback through visual cues like halos and ticks, as well as auditory and haptic feedback. A projected dashboard will display performance metrics such as on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC, updated per trial. The adaptive controller will adjust difficulty and fade feedback based on the user's muscle activation, moving from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results. The gamified environment is intended to increase user motivation during the rehabilitation process.
challenges.summary: The claim states real-time feedback will be provided, but the evidence highlights challenges with stable and consistent feedback mechanisms.
challenges.detail: The claim (c0002) asserts that the system will provide real-time feedback through visual cues like halos and ticks, as well as auditory and haptic feedback. However, evidence E1 indicates significant challenges in achieving this, specifically mentioning 'noisy tilt estimation,' 'inconsistent haptic support,' and difficulties with 'stable spill detecti[on].' This suggests that the intended real-time and consistent feedback may not be reliably achievable with the current system design.

The training will incorporate visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to enhance selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors. challenges.summary: The evidence does not confirm the integration of gamified elements for motivation as described in the claim.

challenges.claim_text: Key technical challenges include anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support. Solutions proposed to mitigate anchor drift involve relocalizing anchors at the session start. Low-pass filtering and debouncing events are suggested for managing tilt estimation and other sensor data. The adaptive controller faces challenges like overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift, which are addressed using moving averages and buffered writes.

IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.
